title: What kind of guitar do you play? - Quora

response.answer_text: My family of guitars (with my pedalboard [as of early-’17] and amp):  I play a variety of music including conventional singer-songwriter stuff, experimental soundscapes, rock & roll (primarily psychedelic and prog rock), ambient, shoegaze, contemporary classical, blues, country, folk, and fusions of those styles, and my equipment covers all those bases for me. Electrically, I prefer Fender guitars for most things and play a Stratocaster (“Ai” [I also refer to her as “青い “ or “Blue”] , my first electric guitar [2001] - Midnight Blue with replacement pickups [Fralin Vintage Strat neck & middle single coils and Steel Poled 43 bridge single coil-sized P-90], shortened vintage-style vibrato arm, and ‘chrome dome’ knobs), Jazzmaster (“Nova” - Sonic Blue with replacement Tortoiseshell pickguard, Warmoth Modified Mustang bridge, and ‘witch hat’ knobs), and Jaguar (“Oni” [鬼] - 3-Tone Sunburst with replacement tune-o-matic bridge). I’d like to get Staytrem bridges for the Jaguar & Jazzmaster as they fix their intonation & tuning instability issues even better than Mustang or tune-o-matic bridges, and I plan on eventually replacing their pickups; I’m considering Curtis Novaks, especially the JM-PAF model which is a hybrid Jazzmaster / ’50s PAF-style pickup. For humbucking sounds, I use an ES-335 style semi-hollowbody Oscar Schmidt Delta King (“Jackyl” - black with white binding, chrome hardware, and PAF-style humbuckers). Future upgrades for it include adding a Bigsby B7 vibrato bridge and replacing the pickups (probably with Lollar or Suhr PAF-style humbuckers) and coil-tapping them via push/pull tone pots for a wider range of tones. Acoustically, I play a 2003 Saga Blueridge steel string, model BR-40 (“Senua” - this photo was taken when it was new; notice how much lighter the wood is compared to the photo of it above taken 14 years later…as with many well-crafted hollowbody guitars, it gets better with age as it sounds deeper and more resonant the more it’s played and the sound passes through the wood). It’s a D-18 style dreadnought with solid spruce top and mahogany back & sides. I’ve always miked it live, but I’m going to get a soundhole pickup to experiment with running it through effect pedals & amplification. I tend to prefer lower output single coils for overdriven higher gain sounds and higher output single coils & humbuckers for cleaner lower gain sounds (as paradoxical as that may seem), but it varies depending on what kind of tone I’m going for.  Oni {Jaguar}, Jackyl (Delta King), and Ai (Strat)  My Fenders: Oni, Nova, and Ai I also consider effect pedals instruments and have what some might consider a fetish for them; my pedalboard changes around depending on what I’m playing, but my signal chain almost always includes 2–4 gain pedals (mainly a ProCo Rat and Fulltone OCD), an equalizer, an analog delay for shorter echoes & oscillation, a digital delay for longer delays & glitching, a reverb, a volume pedal to fade the signal in and out (usually placed later in the chain to mute everything before it and allow the effects after it to linger), multi-effect units (currently a Zoom G3 and MS-70CDR; sadly, the Yamaha Magic Stomp in this image which I’d recorded & gigged with for over ten years died on me last year) which at this point have replaced nearly all my modulation & filter pedals as well as some additional pitch- and time-based ones, and a looper for real-time overdubbing and layering.

First of all I don't want to come off as I'm bragging. I'm not. I have an addiction to guitars. There are just never enough. How many do I need? Just one more! Before I retired I was making pretty good money and bought a new guitar on an average of one a month. I have a collection of guitars that well exceeds over 100. When I reached 100 I stopped counting. I have numerous Fender Stratocasters and Telecasters. I have a Fender Mustang and a Duo Sonic and a Jazzmaster. I have a couple of Gibson Les Pauls and an SG. I also have a solid body Gibson electric that is called “The Paul” I have a Gretcsh 6120 Brian Setzer model. I have a Gretsch Tennessee Rose and a Gretsch Streamliner. I also have a Gretsch Duo Jet and a Gretsch silver sparkle Electromatic. I have an original 60s Harmony Rocket and a Kay Speed Demon. I have a U.S.A. made Ibanez that I don't know the model number off the top of my head. For acoustic guitars I have a Martin D35 and a Martin Shenandoah. I have a Gibson J200 in natural wood finish. I have a couple of Gretsch dreadnaughts and a couple of Epiphone dreadnaughts. I have a Takamine acoustic/ electric and a Sigma acoustic/electric. I have some DeArmond hollow body electrics and some Oscar Schmidt hollow body electrics. I have numerous 3/4 size guitars from the 50s and 60s by Harmony and Stella. I have a National Resonator. I had a solid chrome Dean resonator but I traded it for a car. I also have a couple of Dean solid body mahohany electric guitars. I have a couple of Ibanez Artcore Hollow body guitars. I have all these wonderful and expensive guitars but the one that I play mostly is a Jasmine by Takamine dreadnaught that I found in a dumpster. I checked on Musician's Friend and this guitar retails for around a hundred bucks new. It was missing the strings and bridge but was in otherwise pretty good shape. I bought a replacement bridge and a set of strings and repaired it. I glued on the new bridge and left it clamped for over a week. It probably would have been safe to play in 24 hours but I didn't want to take any chances. It plays and sounds great! I've got a total of $13 invested in it. I don't have a case for it and have it hanging on the wall. Whenever I feel like doing a little picking, I take it down off the wall and start making music. In addition to my guitars I also have three basses. I have a Fender Jazz Bass, A Squier 5 string bass and a Gretsch short scale bass. Between all my guitars, amplifiers, PA System with microphones, stands speakers and cables I would estimate that I have well over 30 thousand dollars invested in musical equipment. I'm 71 years old and should probably sell most of them before I kick the bucket. If by chance my guitars should get stolen or damaged by flood or fire, my homeowners insurance would only pay a fraction of what they are worth.

I like guitars so I have more than a few. I play the ones that are working and rotate pretty frequently through them. The ones that aren’t working are guitars that I’m working on. I keep a few working in my living room so they’re close by if I want to grab something and play. Some of those rotate. Some don’t. Here is what is on deck right now.  This is a Nashville made, ’96 Les Paul Studio Lite. I have had it for nearly twenty years. It was an extraordinary gift from my parents, is still the most expensive thing I have that I don’t live in and has been the guitar I’ve played the most throughout my life. It was the fourth guitar I had growing up. I didn’t buy another one until 2016 actually. The Lite has balsa portions inside of the mahogany body to reduce the weight, an ebony fretboard and Gibson’s 490R and 498T humbuckers. That pair of pickups gets a bit of flak. I would never change them in this thing. They sound great. Recently I noticed some significant fret wear. Part of me wants to put it in the case and stay away so it is still playable many years from now. But what is the fun in that?  The red one here is an ’82 or ’83 Aria Pro II ZZ Deluxe. It was from a box of parts. I don’t have the original serial number and put it together with an ’85 ZZ neck plate. The pickups and about 2/3 of the hardware are original. The tuners are pretty much shot and the bridge has to get swapped (but I’m keeping the ginormous trem block!). I did the best I could to restore the fretboard but there are chips all over. I have it down tuned a step because the truss rod just doesn’t have enough left at this point in its life. There is some neck pocket instability. And several cracks that go all the way through the body. Frets are sprouting right through the cracked nitro again and I just filed them back a couple months ago. Rough winter. But you know what? As long as you have an updated tetanus shot, this thing is fun to play. I have two other ZZ’s in much better shape. But this one has the most personality. Then for something completely different. This is a recent addition B-stock Agile Legacy 727. It is the first Agile I bought from Rondo Music. There are definitely some problems with it but I can’t complain for the price that I received it at. I’ve yet to swap out the pickups (I’m not a fan of the Cepheus sets). I have it down tuned a step and a half with some thicker strings so it covers a frequency range quite different from my other 6 and 7 strings and doesn’t sound sloppy at all. The body just has a light oil finish. Simple. Some people don’t like the beveled off tops. I like it.  Finally in the other corner of the room: the blue one is a cheap full size classical I picked up to work on finger picking. I play electric. I haven’t really used most of the ringers on my right hand to do much. Ever. So I wanted something I could keep close by as a piece of workout equipment. More interestingly, on the wall behind it is an ’83 Quest Atak I in near mint condition minus unavoidable age finish cracks. This thing is just weird. I can’t say I play it that much. It has become a rather permanent wall hanging item. The pickup configuration is similar to a Tele with a humbucker in the neck. But in an offset sort of like Strat/Jazzmaster hybrid shape. The dimensions make it look “small”. It is full 25.5 inch scale. It is just shaped weird. All the Ataks are. It is hard to find much information about these things.

I have and play two kinds of guitars The Recording King RPS-7 Parlor Guitar  I got this for my birthday back in March. It's a new model but it's based off of the Parlor Guitars of the 1930s (that you see a lot of Blues, Folk, and early Country musicians playing (I play alot of that stuff too), It sort of looks like a guitar that you would see in the wild west! I really like the old look of it! It's a Single-O or Parlor sized guitar, I like the Parlor sized guitars because their size is very nice (as compared to a Dreadnought (which I find too bulky) and can be carried around easily. The sound is also very nice (I fingerpick alot and it's really excels at it). It has a solid body and The guitar sells for about $150 and it's definitely a bang for your buck! I would recommend it as a nice acoustic guitar for starters! My other guitar is a Dobro (or a Square Neck Resonator guitar) made by Rogue (which is an import brand (but the instrument is actually pretty good for the price ($200) once you set it up):  As you can maybe see, the neck is thicker and is more square shaped (also the turners are facing up and the string action is much higher (you can’t really fret it down). This is because it is a Steel Slide Guitar and is not meant for the standard way of playing guitar. It's played with a slide usually made of steel (the metal bar on the guitar in the photo is the slide I use) and is put down on your lap (or can be held with a strap) with the strings facing up (the neck is square so it's more comfortable on your lap and also it can handle heavier strings and tunings that normal roundneck guitars can't handle) There are 3 different types of resonator guitars as they have different cones and have a different sound. There is the Tricone, Biscuit, and the Spider cones. Mine is a Spider cone. the Spider cone is usually used in Country-Western and Bluegrass music and has a more nasally tone. Here's a video of my personal favorite Dobro player Pete "Bashful Brother Oswald" Kirby (who played for Roy Acuff and popularised the instrument in Country music) playing a solo song on the Grand Ole Opry:  I find the Dobro really fun! Ever since I heard the sound of the Steel Guitar on the soundtrack of Spongebob when I was young, I always knew I had to play Steel Guitar one day! (Despite not knowing what instrument it exactly was!) (For non-guitars I also own a Banjo (my favorite instrument), a Mandolin, a Alto Saxophone, Harmonicas, a Synthesizer (that I just got for Christmas), and I'm probably forgetting something! ;)

Well, I have a thing for Eric Johnson strats (one of them I actually had signed by him!) and American Deluxe strats, PRS Custom 22s/24s, and LP Specials so I’ve got a few of each, each with its own character. Then a VERY nice playing Gretsch, a ‘78 LP Pro Deluxe (humbucker routed so P90s long gone), and a really beautiful Gibson Johnny A. These things are like children. Can’t really part with any of them. EJ Neck, (Custom) American deluxe body, EJ pickup assembly:  EJ Neck, American deluxe body, SD Lil 59 neck and Screamin Demon bridge, plays & sounds like a dream:  American deluxe neck, EJ body:  American deluxe neck, EJ body, signed (and played) by the man himself on the back bottom bout, literally the best sounding strat I’ve ever played:    Two really special LP specials (the TV Yellow on is a rock monster I mean explosive mojo - something is in that thing):   A beautiful Johnny A:  A wicked ‘78 Pro Deluxe (routed for humbuckers grrrrr which i bought to reverse back to P90 but it sounds so good with these I never did):  A fantastic Indonesian Gretsch G2421 streamliner:  The first “nice” guitar I bought when I was 22, back in 1999, the first PRS I played that I thought was “well worth the money” at $1650 on consignment after playing at least 50 of them over 5 or 6 years. Nothing special, no birds, no 10 top, but toneful sound literally leaps out of this guitar, like it can’t wait to escape. My primary gigging guitar for 15 years. A real treasure and so many good memories:  And then two great PRS’s that aren’t quite as magical as that last one but tools fit for many purposes:   Thanks for looking!!! It’s always nice to show photos of the kids!

I play the acoustic guitar. I currently own a Classical guitar and an Acoustic guitar. The classical looks like this, more or less:  and the acoustic (the one I play 80% of the time) looks kind of like this:   Both of them are gifts though, I didn’t buy any of them myself. The first one -classical- was a gift to my father, from a family friend when we moved from Miami back to Panama. I played the Piano back then, and didn’t care about the guitar, so it was left accumulating dust for years in a deposit until I decided to play it because both my Piano’s broke. Anyway, I learned to play on that one until it eventually broke; or not really broke, it’s more like I have to re-tune it every 30 seconds. After it broke I went to visit a family friend with my father and we stayed a while in the guys living room. He had the Black/Red one -acoustic- on a stand and I asked him if I could play it while he talked with my dad. He said “sure, go ahead” and I went ahead. An eternity later, after he finished talking to my pops I went to put the guitar back and he said “Son, you can keep it if you want to, I barely use it.” And keep it I did. Ever since then I’ve been rocking that red acoustic like Shawn Mendes.  Cause chicks dig guys like that, amiright?  Okay, so those two guitars were given to me purely by chance and not by my own choice. The next time I buy a guitar (or guitars), they’ll be electric-acoustic, so I can plug n’ play. I want a Rainsong Carbon Fiber Electric Acoustic Guitar:  Because it’s beautiful (black and blue! My favorite combo) and it sounds fabulous. I also want one like this:  Because it looks a lot like wood and everyone like wood, right? I don’t think I’ll ever play the electric guitar, it’s not my type of instrument. Cheers!

My guitars come and go most of the time, and to be honest, I’m not super sold on the idea that different woods or whatever make a guitar better. Believe what you want. And, I’d take my Squiers and Epiphones and shitty knockoffs over Fenders or Gibsons any day. Anyways, these are my current guitars, my favorites of all time:  That beauty is an early 2000’s/late 90’s Squier Jagmaster that I recently picked up on Reverb for $200 shipped. Fucking amazing deal on an amazing guitar. It’s got two humbuckers with a three way switch and 2 knobs rewired to be volume knobs for each pup. Everything else is fairly standard and works great. I love it for playing my more Nirvana inspired style, as well as some surprisingly bluesy, White Stripes like stuff when I play it through a big muff.  This is my Epiphone Les Paul Junior Singlecut. I bought it off EBay for around $200. I was looking for a guitar like what Billie Joe played on the American Idiot tour, and when I saw this, I threw every dollar in my possession at it. I fucking love this thing. There’s some cheap humbucker thrown in, and it never stays in tune, yet I fucking love it. The humbucker is hot and punchy, and I actually change my tuning constantly so I don’t mind. It’s great for playing punk, pop punk, and especially some punk blues. I can do anything that’s distorted on this guitar. I don’t play a lot of clean stuff, but I don’t notice a difference between this and the Jagmaster. It’s also great for palm muting. All around, just a great guitar. I love every guitar, but for some reason these just work to me. I love them.

Right now I only have two guitars and they’re both Ibanez Prestige guitars. My newer one has DiMarzzio Tone Zone pick-ups in it and I’m using elixir strings. The newer models have ultra thing necks, which I actually prefer playing over the older model to some degree.  My other guitar is an Ibanez Prestige Giger edition, from about 2006? I think… I don’t remember what pick-ups came stocked in the guitar, but I liked them enough to keep them. This isn’t the earlier model where they just had a painted body, this is one of the carved body guitars with the spinal column styled inlay and carved headstock.  Now that I’ve been recording more I’m looking into getting an ESP M-III loaded with (probably) bare Knuckle pick-ups, to vary up the guitar channels more. While many will advocate that there isn’t much difference in woodtone or things like that, and that’s probably true to an extent since most of your sound is driven by pick-ups anyway. I find that I prefer guitars that cost over a thousand dollars, because for me there’s something about the way those guitars are built that make them far more playable and their construction is overall far better. Are there similar built cheaper guitars? Probably, I just haven’t really found them, so now I prefer to save up and buy something that costs a little more. Just how I’ve noticed things growing up and trying out different guitars here and there and getting into some of my personal preferences on using a guitar. However, when it comes to a beginner, do NOT waste your money on a high end guitar, it really is a waste of money and I think learning on a cheap guitar makes you a better player when you get the really nice guitars. Because if you can make junky equipment sound really good, then good equipment will just sound great! I’ve always learned my instruments on cheap stuff and I think I’ve become a better player for it when I could finally afford nicer quality instruments.

I have a few that I play, choosing just one would be like choosing a favorite child. Here’s a short list of my small collection. Santana SE PRS  This one was given to me, so I honestly don’t know much about it other than the retail price. Gibson Les Paul  I don’t know a whole lot about this one either, other than the fact that is plays great and sounds absolutely amazing. Fender Classic Series Jazz Bass  Technically a guitar right? A bass guitar? I think it counts anyway. C shape neck, vintage style alnico jazz single coil pickups, maple neck, alder body, 20 frets. Ibanez AW54CE  This is an amazing acoustic, and it sounds fantastic. It sounds like a Martin, without the price tag. I sound like a salesman right now, but for $300 you can’t beat this guitar. Mahogany top, back, neck, and sides. Rosewood bridge and fretboard, open pore natural finish. Epiphone PR-4E  This was my first guitar, and it’s a pretty great starter guitar. Not much low end, and some chords (such as D) sound a little funny, but other than that, it’s a pretty good first. And since I have an addiction, this is the small start to an okay collection. Thanks for Reading! :)

I have four right now, but I’m eyeing a really nice Squire Tele that has a lovely twang and crunch—and a really slick fast neck. I’ll update this with some pics as soon as I can find the USB cable to upload my camera-phone pics to the computer. (No internet on my dumb Galaxy S5 smartphone. Expensive and risky) For now, you’ll have to content yourself with my descriptions. (Updated 4/25/19 for pictures) 1987 Fender Japanese Stratocaster—the first year they were assembled in Japan. Arctic white with a maple neck. I paid $399 with case and a Fender guitar cord. The original pickups were really wimpy and that friggin’ five-position Fender switch was crackling like a cheap transistor radio, so I dropped in a set of Fender Tex-Mex pickups and a Switchcraft five-position switch earlier this year. I kept the original wiring configuration. Result: pure magic. It’s LOUD and clean and twangy like SRV’s. (Too bad I can’t play like him.) Standard bridge and vibrato, three springs. This is my main ax. I’m the original owner and I’ll NEVER sell or trade it.  2013 Epiphone Les Paul Special II with the Gibson 490R and 498T design humbuckers. Cherry sunburst just like Tim Lantz’s true Gibson below. Ruler straight neck, smooth and fast. Lightweight—much lighter than a full-on LP Standard or Custom—and quite a joy to switch from fat powerchords to screamin’ leads. I paid $100 for it at a pawn shop here in Tucson. Honest.  1976 Rickenbacker 4001. Burgundy finish. Major mods: a Starz Guitars chrome-plated brass bridge with a little slot for a Strat-style pick-up that I’ve never filled. No need: I use Rotosounds exclusively on her and those have all the treble I’ll ever need. It helps to have a set of Bartolini custom-wound pick-ups, though. Brass nut, too. I had all the lacquer stripped from the deck of the neck and refretted with DiMarzio Jumbo Nickle frets. There’s also a coil tap on the neck pick-up that I rarely use, preferring to keep my lovely beast wide open and work with the dynamics, combinations of various picks, my fingers and thumb, and occasionally a volume pedal. I’ve played around with fx pedals but they all alter her color, her tonality and range. I’m the original owner. I factory-ordered her and paid cash in advance: $695 with case. I was there at Showcase Music in Portland Oregon when they uncrated her. I was the first one to touch her and the first to play her outside of the factory. I’ve had offers of up to $2000 for her because she sounds incredible. No, I will never sell her. My godson Jack gets her when I pass on because he’s a fairly awesome bass player too.  1988 Guild JF-4 NT acoustic guitar. Satin finish. Original owner. I paid $800 with case and it was the best investment I’ve ever made in an acoustic guitar. Deep rich lows, chiming highs, really fat middle. I use a Seymour Duncan in-hole pickup when I need to run her through a direct box and into the PA. (Not the guitar amp. Too harsh.) Gorgeous guitar (VG condition) and a real pleasure to compose with.  I use D’Addario strings exclusively on my guitars, XL’s, .010 - .046 and D’Addario phosphor bronze EJ18–3D, .012 - .053 on my Guild. I did try a set of Ernie Ball Regular Slinkies with a .010 high E on the Guild for a while, but I didn’t like the way they buzzed down in first position. Annoying. So I switched back to the heavier strings and so what if it takes a little more effort? I have a close, personal relationship with my guitars. I create with them and they all deserve my respect, both for the craftsmanship that went into their construction and for the beautiful sounds that come from them. Everybody here knows: when you’re in the Zone with a fine guitar, it’s better than sex. A few more pics: Some of these were taken at an annual outdoor jam called “Camp Up-A-Chuck,” organized and funded by my godson, Jackson Locomotivebreath Conrad-Woldrich. He’s the chubby guy with the beard and the pipe, playing a weird hybrid we called the “FrankenTele.” It was actually a pretty nice guitar, but it had an unpleasant tendency to go out of tune in high humidity—which happens a lot in Oregon. Yeah, I play keyboards too.  My current studio in Tucson, the front left corner of my apartment. (I’m here at the University of Arizona, finishing my master’s degree in Rhetoric, Composition, and Teaching English—RCTE.) My public persona is that of a mild-mannered English teacher but when there’s a call for Truth, Justice, and The American Way of Powerchords, I always respond.

I play 3 different guitars. All of them sound beautiful (my electric is a little too warm for my taste) and look beautiful. My first guitar I got was a beautiful looking and sounding Yamaha Acoustic. Yamaha is underrated, in my opinion, for beginner instruments. I've been told by everyone I know that this guitar sounds beautiful. The most expensive guitar I own coming in at a whopping 300$  My next guitar is my bass. This is an Ibanez bass I bought from a family member for around 150$ and it came with a nice case. This bass plays really well and I can dial in some great tones.  My last instrument is my Epiphone electric. This thing is a great beginner electric guitar. It has a great tone for playing worship music and has a nice blue hue. For only being 140 it sounds great. My only gripes with it are that the tuners aren't great and the place you plug in your cable comes loose sometimes. Other than that it's a great instrument. It's also insanely easy to setup after re-stringing it. Simply put the strings on, adjust the bridge with a screwdriver, and play.

I have a few. My go to electric is my PRS Custom 24. I’ve had it around 15 years and it’s been a lot, probably several hundred of gigs. It holds its tuning well, its term is excellent, and it has great sustain. It’s a pretty versatile axe, and looks the business.  I also occasionally use a Spear RT ST, which is really for show. It sounds okay, but I wouldn't use if I wasn’t dressed for glam rock.  My acoustic is a Yamaha APX500. Not the most expensive of guitar, but it’s really good and plays like something twice the price. It’s been gigged very hard.  I don’t use them as much but I also have a Strat, and Gibson Sonex, which was an 80s budget guitar. That was my first ever electric, so is rather a sentimental piece.

#What kind of guitar do you play? Let me share all of you about best guitars for you as follows: 1. Price $40+: Best Choice Products 38in Beginner Acoustic Guitar Bundle Kit w/Case, Strap, Tuner, Pick, Pitch Pipe, Strings  Rated: 3.5* by 2700+ customers on Amazon 2. Price $100+: Fender CD-60S Dreadnought Acoustic Guitar  Price: $159.99 Rated: 5.4* from 600+ buyers on Amazon 3. Price $200+: Yamaha FS800 Solid Top Small Body Acoustic Guitar  Price: $239.99 Rated: 5* by 30+ customers on Amazon 4. Price &300+: Yamaha FG830 Solid Top Folk Acoustic Guitar  Price: $239.99 Rated: 4.5* by 60+ customers on Amazon 5. Price $400+: Fender CD-140SCE-12 Dreadnought Acoustic-Electric Guitar  Price: $439+ Rated: 4.5* from 210+ customers on Amazon

Ooh, glad you asked! See, my hobby is building and fixing up guitars on a budget that can be called “shoestring” on its best days.  Here's my first guitar, my learning platform - a Squier Bullet Strat that's gone through at least a dozen modifications over the last couple years. Half-scalloped fretboard, a coil-tapped pickup I wound, Gilmour switching. Great modding platform!  My first serious project - a cheap 70’s Strat clone turned 5150.  Another project Strat - made from a horribly trashed body, with all three pickups wired in series. A little muddy for distortion but wonderful phat cleans.  My first kit build, a cheap 335 finished in dyes and Tru Oil. Needs a better nut and lower action, but the tone and feedback are phenomenal for overdriven stuff.  The “Les Plywood” - made of five layers of plywood found in the garage with a random, er, proprietary chambering arrangement. One neck pickup straight to output for max simplicity.  This was a fun project piece - another Strat rescued from an abusive former life! Vaguely Hendrix-inspired relic and reverse-angled bridge pickup. Switching is entirely unique to my knowledge - “normal” mode is neck and bridge in series, like a stretched-out humbucker. “Twang” mode adds the middle pickup out of phase for a sharp, thin tone. Equal parts janky and durable!  The latest build - a plank and a board, a Tru-Oil neck, and a set of hardware. No weird wiring, this'un just does that Tele thing :)

I currently have two that I play. One is a Yamaha F345SY acoustic. I absolutely love the tone of this guitar. It is my primary instrument when I am writing. My other is a Gibson Explorer (1977), that had some modifications made to it when I purchased it. The original pickups were already gone and had been replaced with some Dimarzio super distortions which I did not like. I replaced those with some Seymour Duncan pickups (jazz in the neck position and super humbucker in the bridge position). This gave the guitar a wide range of sound that I absolutely love. I still wish I have all the original hardware, but as I said, it was already modified when I got my hands on it so I made adjustment to get what I wanted out of it. It is still me desire to add a Fender Telecaster to the group. I am primarily a bass player though, so it is not a priority for me.

I play a number of different guitars depending on the requirements for the gig I'm playing. The guitar I play most is a Takamine supernatural series Cedartop rosewood sides and back electric acoustic. I love the response of a Cedartop for finger style playing. If it's an acoustic gig where I need to play harder and more rhythmically, I choose a spruce top over the Cedar for a crisper more percussive sound. if it's an electric gig, my main guitar is a 78 Strat, it's versatile enough to play just about anything. If the gig calls for a heavier rock sound I have a custom built Strat style with dual humbuckers and Gibson type wiring that feels like a Strat, but sounds like a Les Paul. As you can see, I try to cover my bases!

OK, I currently have three guitars: A Taylor Acoustic - it has a pickup installed so I can easily use it for recording and performance. The tone is very good and it is comfortable to play.Epiphone Custom Shop Limited Edition 335 Dot. This is a version of the famous Gibson ES-335. This particular guitar has two Gibson gold cover humbuckers. It is a great electric guitar.A ‘home made’ Stratocaster style electric. This is based on a cheap Chinese kit, but I have fitted a custom neck, and some ‘Tone Rider’ pickups. This sounds like a classic Strat, I like it.I play the electrics through a Vox 35 watt tube amp, the amplifier is definitely a part of the electric guitar, its voice. The Vox is a Tony Bruno model, 2X12″ speakers. Rather like a grittier Fender Twin.With these guitars I am able to play a wide range of guitar music, I would like some more guitars but these 3 do the job nicely. I’d like to get a Les Paul next-this next year maybe.

I play mainly electric guitar. I have 4 electrics and one acoustic in good condition. I have one axe for every different tree  This is my Ibanez Jem jr. it plays awesome and has a lot of great sound in it. It’s my best playing guitar  This Is the most expensive one in my collection Ibanez rgdix7mpb. This thing plays great as well. It’s a 7 string. This thing weighs a ton too. Looks the best in the bunch. It sounds amazing since it has the dimarzio fusion pickups.  This Is my Jackson warrior (not sure shoot the model but it’s one of the made in India ones). I bought it for a very low price. It’s a bit worn Out and is hard to setup but it’s great for being just 150$. I use it in Bb standard tuning.  This is my Epiphone les paul 100. It was my second electric guitar. It has a super sweet neck pickup and traditional sounding bridge. It’s a bit harder to play because of its small scale length against my wide and fat fingers. But it’s awesome nonetheless  This is the last of the bunch. It’s a fender cd60ce semi acoustic. It’s a great instrument and has awesome fish and pickups. I use it very less because I don’t generally play acoustic songs. But it is useful when the time comes

Here are some of mine. i can guitars all the time so what I have changes probably monthly. I’ve added some since this photo and actually traded a few as well. I just got a PRS SE EG that will be arriving today and look forward to playing it. Also on Friday I will receive a 1985 JB Player (not really my kind of guitar) I bought it because it is one of the few neck thru model they ever made and possibly the most high end one they made, It has 2 German made pickups in the mid and neck position and a Seymour Duncan P-90 in the bridge. I also have more that are not pictured. I have too many to list and a few custom builds including one I built myself. I have built several over the years.

Currently I spend most of my time playing fingerstyle chord-melody jazz on a little nylon-string Córdoba “mini” guitar. I’m older and the short scale makes fingering chords a bit easier for my creaky fingers. Now and then I dig out my Taylor GS Mini to keep my flatpicking chops up. I also play mandolin, several different cigar-box guitars I’ve made, as well as a home-made banjo.

I have a lot of guitars. But the guitars I play most are my Wolfgangs. These beauties right below. I have owned everything from a 1953 Les Paul Goldtop (all original. Not a reissue), to a Ken Lawrence “Hetfield” to an Ibanez USA Custom and everything in between. Nothing comes close to these guitars below.  Here’s a shot at my studio with some of my guitars and amps. Can you spot the 1953 Goldtop?

I play a very unique guitar that I built myself. I ordered all the parts from Warmoth. I took the body of a ’72 Fender Telecaster Thinline and the neck of a Fender Stratocaster (added Grover locking tuners) and combined it with Lollar Lollartron pickups which are pickups in the style of the old Gretsch Filtertrons. In the end I have a guitar that has a very smooth, mellow tone, semi-hollow, unique looking, contoured, and plays very well. A video of me playing below
Warwick FNA Jazzman 5-string fretless. I used to have seven basses, but she’s the only one for me now. I’ve become monogabassous.

0:00-0:30 I play a mid 80’s Squier Stratocaster that was made in Japan! My high school English teacher had it lying around and gave it to me when he heard I needed a guitar. It was originally black with a white pick guard; as you can see I refinished the color to a nice sea foam green, and I replaced the electronics and the pickups. It is my go to instrument and has been for several years

I’m not sure which you mean, but here goes. What guitars I own: A Les Paul copyA Telecaster copy with a P-90 neckA Dean ML X hardtailAn OM type acoustic guitar with passive bridgeplate pickupsA Yamaha F-330 with passive bridgeplate pickupsWhat guitars I play: Steel string acousticClassicalElectricWhat styles I play: rockpopfunkfusion

I have more than a few,some have been beat a bit on stages,and some i baby. The Gibson’s are 1991,1995,and 2016. The Strats are built with Warmoth necks and bodies on my kitchen table,but they sound amazing. The Dobro is what I play when I’m alone and no one can hear my shitty slide playing haha. The Epiphone archtop is a very recent purchase but I’m still getting used to it. I used to have some rather badass amps(Mesa Dual Rectifiers and Rivera M100’s) but I’ve stopped playing in public so I sold those and use cheap combos.
My favourite guitar model, is and always will be, the Gibson Les Paul.  My Gibson Les Paul, specifically…       She changes appearance quite a bit, but the raw power in her never changes.

I’ve got a small collection of classical and flamenco guitars, of which I play about 3–4 different ones on a pretty regular basis. Most used one is a Cordoba C7 to which I’ve added golpeadores and an armrest. Its not the “best” guitar by far. . .and I own multiple better ones, but its “good enough” and it works as a suitable beater I don’t mind dragging around. I pretty much never play acoustic guitar, though I do own one. I only very rarely ever play electric guitar, and I own several, with my favorite being a late 80s “Frankenstein: (ie parts built) Stratocaster with jumbo frets. And just for fun, here is a guitar I built (but don’t play). Its a nylon string Telecaster with a classical guitar neck, added abalone dot markers, custom bridge and piezo electronics system.

Yamaha FG 830 I got for Christmas, absolutely stellar after setup, shaved the saddle down almost 1/8″ action is perfect, spruce top very good sound for a $300 Chinese guitar.  '17 Gibson Tribute Plus, sounds and looks great, but I find myself playing the $300 Epi more than anything, this won't stay in tune and the pickups aren't quite what sound I like. I've played many different guitars over the years,but my current stable, although low is growing. Mostly”budget”guitars I've set up or modded slightly;  Alvarez RD26 laminated but done a lot of work to it,total setup..it's a very inexpensive guitar but actually sounds great now,has scalloped bracing. Epiphone Les Paul I I Slash AFD model…i absolutely love this cheap,made in China bolt on neck Pickups are hot,stays in tune easy to work on, sustain is lacking from a traditional LP however.

I have two guitars. One is a Taylor 410ce. It has gorgeous tone, smells good, and I love it. But the case, which is built to protect the guitar from a nuclear blast, is really heavy. So I also have a Taylor Baby, that came in a padded canvas case and is very portable. If I were going to buy another guitar, I’m pretty sure it would be another Taylor, but I’m very happy with what I have.

i have had a fetish of collecting guitars and have almost a good spectrum of them. my Martins sound better always starting from DXCAE, DPA series with Sitka Spruce top and composite back and sides. But i bought recently the HD-28 with sitka spruce top and indian Rosewood back and sides. AWESOME!! Response is immediate and the sustain is out of the world!! My Taylors - series 200 (214ce to be exact) and the 618ce(Grand Orchestra body) sound awesome too. Taylor 618 is also with Torrified top which means it sounds almost like a vintage(if you may!) and is given the ‘aged guitar effect’. well almost that!! The Yamaha Transacoustic is also one of my possessions and the in built Amp is awesome too. But i have to use medium gauge steel strings for it to sound as i like which comprises the bends and pulloffs a lil bit. Rosewood back and sides again in Yamaha. Beautiful piece of art!! Which one I personally enjoy the most?? Well depends on the moment and the mood. Sometimes a relatively humbler Fender acoustic works wonders which the HD28 cannot at that moment!! But since i have to go a long way ahead, as tone appreciation improves, i may zero-in to one only. but i love them all-no favourites!

Depends on the music but the best all rounder is my Epiphone Sheraton. It’s slender neck makes playing easy and its hollow body great for woody jazz tones and harmonic feedback. My fall back guitar is a 1980s Japanese Fender Strat but, while those single coil pickups are great for that “American Blues” sound, I miss the beefy humbucker tone. Fallback guitar number 2 is a Danelectro DC59 (purple finish) - also great for slide playing. One guitar that needs a bit of work but is a beauty to play is a mid-70s Pearl Les Paul which I’ve had for 40 years - one day I’ll get it back to its best - until then it’s the Epiphone for me

1965 Craptone, customized by my teenaged brother in 1974. Shaved vertically to cut down weight and thickness, gobs of varnish layered on, baked in the sun to resemble a brown pizza. Tone resembles a washtub bass, but not as defined:  Just kidding. My joy is my ’70 Jazz Bass, bought for $180 used in 1971. Sweet range of tones, from a bottom-heavy thud to a Ric-like trebly clank-to a snarly growl-to a full, juicy well defined pluck. The GK isn’t shabby either, for small rooms. Its been used for folk-rock, country, hard rock and Praise and Worship:  OldFartBassPlayer Walt

A really cheap one.  That’s what it looks like. It was maybe $30–$40, but it does its job. To be honest, it doesn’t actually sound that bad to me. The strings that came with it were bad, as I read in the reviews, which is why I also bought a really good set of strings. So… it sounds pretty good, in my opinion. It’s called a ZENY. I think it’s OK for someone just starting to play guitar…

DON’T LAUGH! I have a Slammer by Hamer (the one sitting on the floor next to the amplifier), a First Act (bought for me by my husband,and before anyone says he could have picked better, I PICKED IT OUT as it reminded me of the Les Paul Jr that Don Barnes of 38 Special used),and have access to a black Squier Strat (which I used to own but gave it to my husband), AND a Jay Turser Hawk12 (a 12 string guitar),all of which I play through the pictured Marshall MG-30DFX. (And yes, we DO need stands! We also need better cables,too!)
Handmade custom model made to my specifications at their California Custom Shop

Rickenbacker 360/12 12 String, Fender 12 string acoustic, Breedlove Focus 6 string electric / acoustic. Samick Royale 6 string Semi-hollow body electric, Samick Torino, Samick Avion Samick Malibu 6 string electrics, Curbo 5 string bass. Ovation Balladeer , Peavey T-60, Lapatrie Etude Nylon string acoustic, Yamaha Chambered Nylon string electric, Ibanez 6 string electric. Other than that, that’s about it.

I have several, all left handed: A 1970 Martin D-35An el cheapo Harmony classical campfire guitar1964 Fender Jazzmaster (now retired)Ibanez AR 2618 (kinda like a double cutaway Les Paul with a Hipshot b & g bender with a drop d tuner)Fender American Standard 50th Anniversary Strat (now my main axe)(the one I wish that I would have bought when we were a Rickrnbacker dealer) Rickenbacker 360/12

I play a Yamaha FS820. It’s a great-sounding guitar that came for a generally cheaper price. It’s definitely cheaper than a Fender or a Gibson! If you’re looking for a cheap AND good-sounding acoustic, it would probably be a Yamaha FS820 (they come in different colors too!)  I am saving up for a Fender Strat, one that looks like this:

My electric is an Ibanez RG350DX  My previous guitar I believe was an Ibanez RG570 from around 1989, although the model is somehow not printed anywhere on the guitar? I also have a fairly old Yamaha acoustic that despite being a lower range guitar plays beautifully loud and bright.

I play a Fender Stratocaster through a 100 watt Marshall Super Lead. I can't emphasize enough how awesome Fender guitars are. Don't get me wrong, Gibson is bad ass, too, but Fenders shreik like a banshee!! Everything else is 2nd choice. Imho.

My weapon of choice is a 2010 Mexican Fender Stratocaster. My wife bought it for me about 5 years ago and I love it. I’ve bought and sold many guitars over the years but this baby I will never part with. It has been through several mods over the time I’ve owned it and is currently sporting all black hardware on its Olympic white body and all maple neck. Pickups are mid 1990s vintage Seymour Duncan Hot Rails running through CTS pots. Awesome tones from a stunning instrument

A heavily modified Japanese Stratocaster. Mods include:1. Roland GK-2 pickup2. other multi-tap regular pickups with anti-resonance foam3. heavy shielding4. my own controlled acoustic feedback system - hear the basic sound here: https://www.reverbnation.com/thetaxciter/song/30246274-taxocaster-demo5. bone nut, Sperzel locking tuners, etc. This is my research “mule”, and I play it more than any other.

Electric are a Gibson les paul standard and Deluxe, fender Strat and telecaster as well as a godin LGXT. Acoustic are Takamine EN60c nylon from 1985 ( i love it!) A lakewood Baritone ( utterly incredible) and a taylor 810 plus a Leo Kottke 12 string. I also use a takamine Santa fe for horsing around as it’s fun to play but doesn’t have the power or projection of the taylors / lakewood!

Oh … just a minute… I think you got a confusion about guitars … What kind of guitar … guitar which is not bend, well tuned , give good sound & easy fret shifting But if you want to ask - what type of guitar or which guitar… then my answer is acoustic guitar … because I like it more then electric … just like that .

I also play a Squier Strat from 2002, first guitar I ever had then upgraded to a Fender Stratocaster white on white maple fretboard and sold it :/ but the Squier Strat I use is basic but it sounds amazing with the EHX Big Muff Pi, and a Marshall half stack. Really want a Gibson LP or epiphone lp miss the Stratocaster…

Too hard to answer that one. I have 39 guitars and only a few are the same brand. I usually play the one closest to me so I rotate them every couple of weeks. I enjoy each one and appreciate each for it's own unique sound and feel. But currently playing my Gibson Songwriter acoustic the most. But I just got it a few weeks ago.
None, I'm at work right now. When I'm at home it's one of 3. Chapman Ghost Fret Pro 6 string, BC Rich Jr. V 7 string or Ibanez RG8.

Acoustically: a Yamaha NTX700 Electrically: Still waiting for it to come back, but a Squier Telecaster Custom with an HH setup in black. I mostly play pop punk (Green Day, All Time Low, etc) and I also dabble in metal.
I like to play acoustic guitar. Its sound gives a satisfactory soothing effect to ears. I also want to play an electric guitar, though not got my hands on one till now, but hope to try it soon.

‘57 Gibson J-50, ‘60 Mosrite Dobro, 2000’s Takamine 6 cutaway, Aria nylon string, Fernandez strat clone, Fender Telecaster, Ibanez Artist, ‘73 Yamaha 12 string acoustic, ‘91 Fodera 6 string bass guitar, 90’s Fender fretless Jazz, off brand 4 string acoustic guitar bass. Had a Les Paul and Guild ‘SG style’ electrics back in the day.
I'm playing an Epiphone Les Paul Custom Classic Pro with Gibson 490/498 humbuckers:

Ive got a Jackson Rhoads V, a Gibson SG, and a Yamaha Pacifica to scratch my Stratocaster itch when it flares up. There's a Washburn 12string acoustic next to my bed missing half the strings, sounds HUGE as a six string. Missing are a 7string king V, a Parker Fly, and a Seagull acoustic electric. Need to move the Rhoads and Gibson and do some horse trading I guess.
I play a 1977 Gibson Super 400. My other guitar is 1950s Gibson ETG 150 4-string tenor guitar.

I started taking guitar lessons recently and i'm practicing on a Eagle Ch 888.  But in the future i would like to have a Martin D-18E Acoustic-Electric Guitar. It's the same model Kurt used on MTV Unplugged in New York.
I am playing this one a lot
I generally play the Aria/Acoustic Guitar ADL-01Black
Nothing too fancy… Just a b. C. Rich.eelectric….epiphone Les Paul custom
I love old acoustics lol I play a yamaha f335, then either the tele or the strat

Stratocaster. 50th Anniversary with Texas shop pickups. Also a Dan Smith model Strat. It only has one volume and one tone pot. The jack goes into the front of the guitar where the third pot would normally be.
The kind that gives me the sound I want at that moment
A very kind acoustic guitar.
Epiphone 1966 G-400 PRO Were it up to me, I’d own this bad boy right here: Ibanez M80M 8-String Meshuggah Signature Electric Guitar
